stream_context.summary: Kaze designs the inside-of-the-pyramid sub-area for Course 14 (papercraft/cardboard world), aiming for an 8–red-coin mission that initially feels maze-like but becomes easy to navigate once the player understands its structure. He also shows an off-stream-finished, very difficult saw/timer sub-area (Course 15), discusses movement/controls philosophy, discovers a BLJ-related physics bug, and brainstorms how to communicate a global coin counter system to players.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a clear articulation of RTY’s level-design goal (“confusion that resolves”), a concrete structural plan for Course 14’s pyramid red-coin sub-area, a reveal of a new hardest sub-area finished off-stream with Zeina playtesting feedback, and a newly discovered movement/physics bug (BLJ) that needs fixing.

findings.summary: Course 14’s pyramid interior is planned as an 8–red-coin sub-area that should feel like a cave/maze at first, but become straightforward once the player unconsciously recognizes the underlying structure (more ‘confusion resolves’ than a deliberate logic puzzle).
findings.quote: I want this to be more like confusion and then the confusion resolves, because you understand it.

findings.summary: Kaze rejects making the pyramid interior a ‘labyrinth’ solved by wall-following; he plans to use one-way elements (one-way doors/paths) specifically to defeat the ‘follow the left wall’ strategy and force real navigation decisions.
findings.quote: I want some one-ways in there so you can’t just do the follow-left-wall strategy, because it ruins every maze instantly.

findings.summary: After exploring multiple concepts (central overlook room, color-coded routing, clock/octagon hub, footprints/visited-path coloring), Kaze converges on a more buildable structure: one main path through the pyramid with multiple branching shortcut paths that reconnect to the main path; the shortcuts contain the red coins, and the optimal route involves taking a shortcut, grabbing a coin, then backtracking slightly to continue to the next shortcut.

Kaze identifies a readability problem: players must be able to tell ‘forward vs back vs shortcut,’ and he considers environmental signposting like floor arrows, coin arrows, or using enemy movement direction as an implicit guide (later noting ants may clash with the desired enemy set).

Kaze shows a Course 15 sub-area finished off-stream featuring timed saw hazards that trigger based on player proximity; the system includes rubber-banding where saw speed adapts to player speed, creating pressure to keep moving while avoiding a harsh global time limit.

Difficulty balancing becomes a concern: Kaze calls the saw area the hardest in the game so far; Zeina struggled to beat it, but Kaze currently believes the difficulty is acceptable for Course 15 (late-game) while still worrying about accessibility.

Kaze encounters a major, unexpected movement/physics issue related to BLJ (backwards long jump) behavior and flags it as an important bug to investigate and fix; chat suggests it may involve a ‘C value.’
findings.quote: Apparently you cannot BLJ. Oh my god. That’s a very important bug to fix.

findings.summary: Kaze’s movement-design stance: new/adjusted moves (e.g., dive variants) should be optional and never required for completion; instead of accessibility toggles, players can simply ignore optional tech if they dislike it.
findings.quote: This move is never required to beat the game… you have the option to just not use it.

findings.summary: Kaze explicitly avoids puzzle-heavy gating (e.g., password/ladder-room sequences) because it clashes with RTY’s broader design; even puzzle-themed content should be more about noticing the ‘puzzle-ness’ than solving complex logic.
Course 14 (papercraft level) is close to completion: Kaze says only two areas are missing in the papercraft level, and once the pyramid interior sub-area is finished, Course 14 will be complete.
Kaze considers enemy/theme coherence in the pyramid interior: ants could help communicate directionality, but he notes they may not fit the area’s intended enemy roster (bombs and Whomps).

Kaze discusses a potential global coin counter system (coins persist across levels) and how to teach it without explicit exposition; he leans toward demonstrating it via overworld design (e.g., earn coins in an early hub/town, spend them, and enter a level carrying coins). He does not want 100-coin stars to be part of 100% completion in RTY.
Kaze floats a UI hint for global coins (always display coin count as four digits, e.g., 0100) to imply totals above 999, but he dislikes the look and thinks world design is a better tutorial.
A previously planned ‘dojo’/tutorial area to teach new moves existed, but was largely moved into Course 1; Kaze is no longer sure the dojo is still needed at all.

Kaze briefly contextualizes finances and sustainability: his YouTube revenue is modest (he cites about $900 for the month and ~$10k/year) and he frames long-term mod development as driven by personal compulsion rather than practicality.
findings.quote: When you spend a decade doing mods without it being a job… yeah, but I’m literally insane. I don’t count here.

biobak.summary: Biobak participates as a live design sounding board while Kaze brainstorms the pyramid interior’s readability and structure (e.g., reacting to ideas like signposting and discussing difficulty expectations).

Biobak suggests an art-direction adjustment for the papercraft level’s ‘styrofoam’ material: instead of the current look, use cardboard with stapled paper layered onto it to make the surfaces feel more believable within the craft theme.

zeina.summary: Zeina playtests the newly finished saw sub-area (Course 15) and struggles to beat it, which becomes Kaze’s main reference point for whether the difficulty may be too high for players.

findings.summary: ZeroVolt appears in chat; during music playback Kaze references a track concept with biome-based music switching (happy house theme → mountain theme) that will be used to add atmosphere and spatial identity to an area of the game.

key_stories.title: Designing a maze that stops being a maze (Course 14 pyramid interior)
key_stories.summary: Kaze needs the pyramid interior to feel like an intricate cave/maze for an 8–red-coin mission, but he wants players to eventually ‘get it’ and navigate confidently. He cycles through multiple concepts (landmarks, central overlook, color coding, hub-and-spokes, visited-path coloring) before settling on a simpler structural solution.
key_stories.challenge: Create a red-coin area that feels confusing initially but becomes legible without turning into an explicit logic puzzle or a wall-following labyrinth.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed ‘confusion-resolving’ mechanics; rejected puzzle-password concepts as off-tone; targeted wall-following prevention via one-way routes; evaluated technical feasibility (e.g., dynamic ‘visited’ coloring/footprints deemed too complex); designed a main-path + branching-shortcut topology where red coins live on shortcuts.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete plan emerges: one main path through the interior with ~8 shortcut branches that loop back; Kaze now needs to implement signposting/readability (forward/back/shortcut) and then texture/iterate for fun platforming.
key_stories.key_quote: I want some one-ways in there so you can’t just do the follow-left-wall strategy.

key_stories.title: Finishing and validating the hardest sub-area so far (Course 15 saw area)
key_stories.summary: Kaze reveals an off-stream-finished saw-focused sub-area that he calls the hardest in RTY so far. The hazard timing is proximity-triggered and includes rubber-banding so the danger scales with player movement speed.
key_stories.challenge: Make a high-pressure late-game obstacle course that is tough but still fair and readable.
key_stories.process: Built proximity-based timers for hazards; tuned a rubber-banding behavior (slower player → slower saws) to reduce frustration; color-coded individual pieces for readability; used Zeina’s playtest difficulty as a gut-check.
key_stories.outcome: Area is implemented and playable; Kaze still worries it may be too difficult, but currently accepts it as appropriate for Course 15.

key_stories.title: Unexpected BLJ-related movement regression
key_stories.summary: While demonstrating movement, Kaze discovers BLJ behavior is not what he expects and labels it as a critical bug. The moment highlights how small physics/movement parameter changes can have far-reaching side effects in SM64-derived engines.
key_stories.challenge: A newly observed movement/physics inconsistency that could affect exploits, speed, feel, or intended traversal.
key_stories.process: Immediate on-stream testing; chat proposes a parameter (‘C value’) as a likely culprit; Kaze notes he needs to locate the underlying cause.
key_stories.outcome: Bug is flagged as high priority for later debugging; no fix occurs in this stream.
key_stories.key_quote: That’s a very important bug to fix.

key_stories.title: Teaching global coins without telling the player
key_stories.summary: Kaze explores how to make players understand that coins persist globally across the game, while avoiding explicit tutorial text or a 4th-wall-feeling solution. He considers UI hints and overworld demonstrations.
key_stories.challenge: Communicate a non-standard system (global coins; no 100-coin completion requirement) clearly and naturally.
key_stories.process: Rejected ‘just tell them’ and disliked a forced ‘buy a boat ticket’ tutorial as too 4th-wall; considered 4-digit coin UI as a hint; leaned toward overworld staging where players collect/spend coins and then enter a course with coins already in inventory.
key_stories.outcome: No final decision, but he plans to note an overworld solution; overall direction is environmental teaching rather than UI/text explanation.

key_stories.title: Course 14 nearing completion, but still needs coherence and textures
key_stories.summary: Kaze states Course 14 is close to finished, with only two missing areas in the papercraft level, and the pyramid interior is the current blocker. He also calls out remaining work: textures, coin placement, and making platforming less boring once visuals are in.
key_stories.challenge: Convert a functional blockout into a polished, coherent papercraft sub-area that plays well and reads clearly.
key_stories.process: Blocked out the interior, placed red coins and main-route coins, identified signposting needs, and discussed material tweaks (styrofoam vs layered cardboard).
key_stories.outcome: A workable layout exists and coin placement is underway; next steps are texturing and iteration for fun/clarity.

open_questions.topic: Course 14 pyramid interior: final navigation readability plan
open_questions.context: Kaze has a main-path + shortcut topology but is unsure how players will reliably distinguish forward/back/shortcut at a glance (arrows, coin arrows, enemy motion cues, door logic, color accents).
questions: What exact visual language did you settle on to communicate ‘this is the shortcut’ and ‘this is forward’ (color rings, trims, lighting, props, enemy behavior)?
How did you playtest whether players ‘get it’ at the intended moment, and what metrics/observations told you the confusion resolved?
Did one-way routes create frustration for players who made ‘wrong’ choices, and how did you mitigate that?

open_questions.topic: Course 15 saw area: rubber-banding implementation and tuning
open_questions.context: Hazards start timers by proximity and scale speed based on player speed, creating constant pressure without a single harsh time limit.
questions: How is the rubber-banding implemented (what variables drive saw speed, and how do you prevent it from feeling inconsistent or ‘cheaty’)?
What made this area ‘the hardest so far’—reaction time, camera, punishment, length, or checkpointing?
After Zeina’s playtest struggle, did you adjust anything (damage, cycle timing, camera, recovery options)?

open_questions.topic: BLJ-related bug: what broke and why it matters
open_questions.context: Kaze flags unexpected BLJ behavior as a major bug; chat mentions a possible ‘C value’ parameter being involved.
questions: What precisely changed—was BLJ unintentionally disabled, enabled in new spots, or behaving differently due to slope/velocity code changes?
Do you want RTY to preserve BLJ as a freedom/expression tool, or are you trying to remove it for design reasons?
What ended up being the root cause, and did fixing it affect other movement tech?

open_questions.topic: Global coin counter: final player onboarding
open_questions.context: Kaze wants global coins (and no 100-coin completion requirement) but doesn’t want explicit tutorial text; he considers overworld demonstrations and rejects 4th-wall solutions.
questions: What did you ultimately choose to teach the global-coin concept—overworld event, UI treatment, NPC hint, or implicit discovery?
How does global coin persistence interact with death, level exit, or re-entering courses?
What role do coins play in progression (optional rewards, shops, cosmetics, gating), and how did that evolve?

open_questions.topic: Course 14 completion timeline and remaining two missing areas
